Appendix 5: Pathway for Under  years requiring EWMHS Crisis Mental Health
Appendix 6: Escalation Procedure when a Young Person Requires a Psychaitric Inpatient Bed………………………………………………………………………………………………………….34

Appendix 7: Pathway for Children attending ED or PAU with an eating Disorder…………..35 Appendix 8: CEWT Score charts……………………………………………………………………..36 Appendix 9: Preliminary Equality Analysis…………………………………………………………44
Purpose
This Standard operating Procedure applies to all children attending the Paediatric Emergency Department. The procedure highlights the patient flow and management.
Aim
To provide an efficient assessment facility for all children and young people who present to the emergency department.

This is undertaken by suitably qualified staff (NSF 2003) and achieved by working together with other departments/agencies to safeguard children using local SET procedures(2006) and national policy and guidelines Every Child Matters, Choice for Children 2004, Children's Act 1989,
To ensure children are assessed, treated and discharged or referred to the relevant specialty teams or admitted as quickly as possible and within a 4 hour target from arrival in ED.
To ensure children, young people and their families are fully informed as to the process from the moment of arrival.
Operational Hours and Pathways
Hours of opening: 24 hours – Children's Emergency Department (ED).
Categories of children seen: All children between 0-16 years.
Special cases:
16-19 year old young people who have complex chronic conditions, including diabetes, who are already under the care of paediatricians.
3.3.1 New diabetics up to the age of  years will be managed by the Paediatric Team.

3.3.2 A yellow card system operates under the supervision of the paediatric consultants, resulting in individually selected patients (based on their conditions) having direct parental access to the paediatric assessment unit.

3.3.3 All patients who are known or likely to be immuno-compromised, such as oncology patients, should not be assessed in Children's ED and have direct access to the paediatric assessment unit via the yellow card system. If they arrive by ambulance and are significantly unwell they should be brought to ED in line with any other significantly unwell child and the Paediatric team should be informed immediately.
Operational Management
Joint Medical Staffing for Paediatric ED.
The day to day operational management of all nursing staff within paediatric ED is the responsibility of the Women's and Children's Division.

There is a designated Paediatric Lead for ED who sits within the medicine and Emergency care working in collaboration with the lead for Paediatric ED within Women's and Children's for education, clinical governance, training, Audit and policy and pathway's.

The Paediatric Assessment unit is located presently on Phoenix Ward (Acute Children's Ward) this is managed by the Division of Women's and Children's and will provide support and guidance and work in collaboration with the ED staff to ensure high standards of care for children and young people.
Clinical Areas
The acute assessment areas for children comprise two clinical areas, Children's ED and the Paediatric Assessment Unit.
The Children's ED has 2 triage rooms, 2 majors' cubicles, 3 standard cubicles, 1 isolation room and a plaster room.

The Children's ED has designated waiting / play area that is separate to the adult waiting area. It provides an entry point into the trust for all CYP who present for emergency treatment or assessment.
The Children's ED has a dedicated resuscitation bay within ED Resuscitation area incorporating a resuscitaire and bed space.
The PAU has 1 cubicle, 8 beds and a waiting area and indoor and outdoor play area.
Clinical Responsibility
Doctors Responsibility:

6.1.1 Patients arriving in ED: The responsibility of individual patients lies with the ED consultant on call before referral to and review by other Specialities (including Paediatrics, Surgeons, Orthopaedics, Ears Nose Throat (ENT), Max-fax, Plastics and Burns and others), they are then the joint responsibility between the Speciality consultant on call and the ED Consultant on call whilst in the ED department and the responsibility of the Speciality Consultant on-call once they leave the ED. The paediatric ED consultant/consultant on-call should be involved in the care of any critically unwell child, regardless of the main speciality input required.
6.1.2 Patients arriving in areas other than ED:
The responsibility of individual patients lies with the admitting Speciality consultant on call.

The paediatric ED consultant/Paediatric consultant on-call should be involved in the care of any critically unwell child, regardless of the main speciality input required. Please see below the role of new Paediatric ED consultants (section 7.0).
Nursing and allied health professionals
Children's ED will be staffed by dedicated registered children's nurses and supported by ED nurses and Emergency Nurse Practitioners (ENP)

The nursing staff will be responsible for the child's care in collaboration with the family, advocate for the child and family, regular observations, dispensing medication, care of property and valuables (in line with Trust policy), moving and handling of patients, appropriate paperwork and admission documentation.
The Paediatric Band 7's are responsible for ensuring that all checks and compliance actions are done in accordance with trust policy as well as supporting the staff.

The nursing staff may also play a part in expediting patient assessment (following Trust training) by inserting cannula, taking appropriate blood tests, organising investigations (urinalysis, Eco-cardiogram (ECG), Blood Monitoring (BM), swabs), liaising with radiology for X-rays.
The nurse in charge will coordinate the flow of children through the units and encourage timely decision-making processes by the on-call teams.
System One checks to be completed on all patients with injuries and for all children with suspected safeguarding concerns in accordance with safeguarding processes.
Nursing staff will be responsible for the transfer and handover of patient care to the appropriate definitive treatment area by using SBAR (Situation Background assessment and recommendation) tool.
Outline description of the role of the new Paediatric ED consultants
Bleep 1123 will be carried at all times when a senior Paediatric ED Doctor is covering the Paediatric ED.
Cover arrangements are as follows:
x Paediatric ED Consultants will be available in Paediatric ED Monday to Thursday between 08:45 to 21:15 (excluding bank holidays)
Paediatric ED Consultants will be available in Paediatric ED on Friday 09:30 to 16:45 (excluding bank holidays)
A Paediatric registrar designated to ED may be available in Paediatric ED on Fridays 16:45 to 21:15 (excluding bank holidays) depending on the availability.

In the absence of Paediatric ED consultant, this may be back filled by a Paediatric registrar if available this cover will only be provided between 08:45 and 17:15 on these dates. This will not always not be possible due to lack of existing resources currently. Once there are enough resources, the gaps will be filled more regularly in the future(details of how to access this information for any given date will be circulated separately (in brief see http://meht-intranet/clinical-pages/doctors-rosters PAEDIATRIC REG + SHO Roster 2019-2020 and click on “ED Consultant rota” tab)
The primary aim of this new role is to improve the quality of care provided to the children who attend our Paediatric ED department; this will include (but is not limited to):
The above aims will be achieved by working closely with the existing ED teams.
For all patients who present to Paediatric ED:
Doctors who are expected to attend all Paediatric resuscitation (crash and trauma) calls:
Emergency and Acute Care Pathway

All children and young people are streamed after arrival in ED by a registered Nurse with the exception of direct access Paediatric cases (Yellow card holders, Oncology/immunocompromised patients and GP referrals) who go directly the Paediatric Assessment Unit on Phoenix ward.
All children or young people with a suspicion of a non-accidental injury or where there is a safeguarding concern (Refer to the ‘Safeguarding Children Policy'; register number 04064).
Paediatric Emergency Department Patient Flow
All walk in attendances follow the below process:
Booked in at reception
On arrival either the child, young person or their representative will be requested to confirm their personal information is accurate on the Electronic Patient Record (EPR) system.
The receptionist will establish the relationship of the person accompanying the child or young person and document this in the patient's notes.

The receptionist will establish if the address given for the child is the usual place of residence or a temporary address. Where the child is staying in temporary accommodation, the child's permanent and temporary address will be recorded
Patients will be admitted on to Lorenzo
Triaged in Children's ED by a registered Nurse with Paediatric Qualification or experience.
The child / young person will be seen in order of priority as highlighted by the Manchester Triage System or Children's Early Warning Tool (CEWT).

System One is checked for all children who are known to Social Care , have a CPIS alert on Lorenzo or who have attended with certain criteria requiring a Systmone Check such as Head Injury under 1 year, any fracture under  months old.
Seen by appropriate team as below:
Assessed and appropriate management initiated by ED team.

If ≤10 day old should be discussed with ED Paediatric Consultant (if available) who will specify where the baby should be seen (i.e. ED or PNW), if the baby is deemed suitable to be sent to PNW then the ED nurses should refer to the Neonatal registrar (bleep 3522) and inform the receiving area about the baby's transfer.

If >10 days and younger than  months (13 weeks) of age should be discussed with ED Paediatric Consultant (if available) who will specify where the baby should be seen, if stable and safe to transfer, the baby should be transferred to PAU for review by Paediatric team after referral to the Paediatric Registrar on bleep 3520.
If older than  months (13 weeks) and without fever up to  months (26 weeks), should be seen by ED Doctors (including all ED doctors/ED Paediatric Consultant/ED consultants) or Paediatric ENP.

If younger than 6 months (26 weeks) of age with fever history or fever present at triage, should be discussed with ED Paediatric Consultant (if available) who will specify where the baby should be seen, if stable and safe to transfer, the baby should be transferred to PAU for review by Paediatric team after referral to the Paediatric Registrar on bleep 3520. This will be reviewed in 6 months' time.
Referral to speciality if required
Please see “Care of the critically ill child”, policy No 16025” for escalation policies in relation to clinically deteriorating patients
Treatment commenced/completed.
Exit ED by either being:
Discharged home (refer to Children's Discharge Policy 09026)
Transfer to PAU for further assessment/admission.
Transfer to another hospital for definitive care (e.g. Paediatric intensive care unit (PICU), tertiary surgical centre, trauma centre, no bed capacity)
Appropriate follow up planned as required depending on ED exit location

For children and young people who are being discharged, the discharging nurse will ensure that the patient has the appropriate discharge advice sheet which has been documented in the patient record, any prescribed medications which they have checked and explained to the child/young person and carers and have provided an information leaflet. (Refer to Children's Discharge Policy 09026)
Summary letter sent to General practitioner (GP).
Ambulance referrals (non-critically unwell patients):
Child brought into Children's ED.
Ambulance service provide information and book in whilst they are assessed by Children ED Nurse.
Triaged in Children's ED.
The child / young person will be seen in order of priority as highlighted by the Manchaester Triage System or Children's Early Warning Tool (CEWT).
System One Check in criteria as stated previously.
Seen by appropriate team as below:

If ≤10 day old should be discussed with ED Paediatric Consultant (if available) who will specify where the baby should be seen (i.e. ED or PNW), if the baby is deemed suitable to be sent to PNW then the ED nurses should refer to the Neonatal registrar (bleep 3522) and inform the receiving area about the baby's transfer.

If >10 days and younger than 3 months (13 weeks) of age should be discussed with ED Paediatric Consultant (if available) who will specify where the baby should be seen, if stable and safe to transfer, the baby should be transferred to PAU for review by Paediatric team after referral to the Paediatric Registrar on bleep 3520.
If older than 3 months (13 weeks) and without fever up to 6 months (26 weeks), should be seen by ED Doctors (including all ED doctors/ED Paediatric Consultant/ED consultants) or Paediatric ENP

If younger than 6 months (26 weeks) of age with fever history or fever present at triage, should be discussed with ED Paediatric Consultant (if available) who will specify where the baby should be seen, if stable and safe to transfer, the baby should be transferred to PAU for review by Paediatric team after referral to the Paediatric Registrar on bleep 3520. This will be reviewed in 6 months' time.
Assessed and appropriate management initiated by appropriate team.
Referral to speciality if required.
Refer to “Care of the critically ill child” (16025) for escalation policies in relation to clinically deteriorating patients.
Treatment commenced.
Exit ED by either being:
Discharged home (refer to  Children's Discharge Policy 09026)
Transfer to PAU for further assessment/admission.
Transfer to another hospital for definitive care (e.g. PICU, tertiary surgical centre, trauma centre, no bed capacity)
Appropriate follow up planned as required depending on ED exit location.
Summary letter sent to GP.
Ambulance referrals (critically unwell patients)
Call received to red phone in adult department.
Nurse in-charge places 2222 call “Paediatric Trauma” or “Paediatric cardiac arrest call”.
Child brought straight in to Paediatric Resuscitation Bay.
Appropriate team arrivals.
Seen, assessed and appropriate management initiated by appropriate teams.
Refer to “Care of the critically ill child”; register number 16025 for escalation policies in relation to clinically deteriorating patients.
Referral to further speciality if required.
Treatment commenced.
Exit ED by either being:
Transfer to PAU for further assessment/admission.
Discharged home (refer to Children's Discharge Policy 09026).
Transfer to PAU/HDU for further assessment/admission.
Transfer to another hospital for definitive care (e.g. PICU, tertiary surgical centre, trauma centre, no bed capacity).
Appropriate follow up planned as required depending on ED exit location.

For children and young people who are being discharged, the discharging nurse will ensure that the patient has the appropriate discharge advice sheet which has been documented in the patient record, any prescribed medications which they have checked and explained to the child/young person and carers and have provided an information leaflet . (Refer to Children's Discharge Policy 09026)

Any Children and Young people requiring external specialist review or transfer, a copy of the notes will be copied placed in a sealed envelope marked private and confidential and given to the guardian for transfer.
Summary letter sent to GP.
Patients with Mental Health Issues

9.3.1 Patients that attend the emergency department with mental health issues will be assessed by the triage nurse which will include a full history and a full set of observations and then placed in a room (where available). Also the risk absconder assessment must be completed in the ED notes including a description of the patient and what they are wearing.

9.3.2 The patients will be then be seen by the ED doctors and if medically fit for discharge they will then be referred to the CRISIS team for EWMHS ( Emotional Wellbeing and Mental Health Services) where they will take the details and advise the referrer if and when the patient will be seen in the ED for a mental health assessment.
9.3.3 If the patient requires medical treatment then the CRISIS team will not assess until the patient has completed the treatment and deemed fit for discharge.

9.3.4 When the assessment has taken place by the CRISIS team a plan of care will be drawn up and the patient will either go home with outpatient follow up if necessary or they may require admission to a Tier 4 Specialist Unit.

9.3.5 In the case of the patient requiring a mental health bed and there are none available the patient will be looked after in the most appropriate environment ,taking into account the safety of not only them but the other patients attending the ED and where admission is necessary the safety of the inpatients. Also the children's ward bed availability / capacity and safe staffing levels.

9.3.6 If the sourcing of a Tier 4 bed is to take some time then a multi disciplinary meeting via conference call should be convened at the earliest possible opportunity to clarify the care pathway for the patient and to ensure the care needs are met for them during their stay in the ED and possible subsequent admission to the children's ward.

9.3.7 If there are outside carers accompanying the patient then their responsibilities to the patient whilst in the hospital need to be defined and clarified with the hospital staff and a careplan written and agreed by both parties.
Paediatric Assessment Unit Patient Flow (co-located within Children's Ward)
The Patient flow through PAU is described below:
Booked in at PAU reception

On arrival either the child, young person or their representative will be requested to complete a Patient Registration Form to ensure all of their personal information is accurate on the Electronic Patient Record (EPR) system.
Patients will then be admitted onto the Lorenzo.
Triaged in Paediatric Assessment Unit.
The child / young person will be seen in order of priority as highlighted by the Triage or Children's Early Warning Tool (CEWT).
Seen by speciality doctor that meets child's needs (depending on source of referral),
referrals include:
Yellow card holders (self-referrals) – seen by Paediatric Team.
GP referrals - seen by Paediatric Team.
Open access patients (recently discharged from PAU) – seen by team providing the open access.
Speciality referrals from other sites – seen by appropriate team.
Oncology patients - seen by Paediatric Team.
Diary patients – seen by team providing appointment in diary.
Assessed and appropriate management initiated by appropriate teams.
Refer to Care of the critically ill child Policy (16025) for escalation policies in relation to clinically deteriorating patients.
Referral to further speciality if required.

For children / young people requiring admission to the children's ward, the Children's PAU nurse in charge of the children's area will be advised so that an appropriate bed can be identified and transfer arrangements can be agreed.
Treatment commenced.
Exit PAU by either being:
Discharged home refer to Children's Discharge Policy (09026)
Transfer to another hospital for definitive care (e.g. PICU, tertiary surgical centre, trauma centre, no bed capacity)

For children and young people who are being discharged, the discharging nurse will ensure that the patient has the appropriate discharge advice sheet which has been documented in the patient record, any prescribed medications which they have checked and explained to the child/young person and carers and have provided an information leaflet , a Nurse Discharge letter will be given to the parents/guardians to sign and a copy returned to them.

Any Children and Young people requiring external specialist review or transfer, a copy of the notes will be copied placed in a sealed envelope marked private and confidential and given to the guardian for transfer.
Summary letter sent to GP.
Special Cases:

Paediatric 2222 calls: 2222 call placed stating “Paediatric Trauma” or “Paediatric cardiac arrest” and specifying location. Appropriate team crash bleeped by switch board to attend. Management as appropriate to situation encountered. Aim to get child to area where critical care can be provided as soon as practicable.
Paediatric Trauma:

10.3.1 Any major trauma or significant injury to any child (including neonates) that presents to ED should be discussed with our linked major trauma centre (Addenbrookes) via a designated number (clearly shown on all trauma paperwork in ED).

10.3.2 This telephone number (option 3) takes you directly to the on call trauma consultant hours a day; they can provide clinical management advice and further advice on transfer methods/practicalities.
10.3.3 They can also connect in other specialists to the call in real-time if required or get the

specialist, such as a neurosurgeon, to call back immediately if required.If the above trauma pathway is not accessible or has not met the needs of the child then the Children's Acute Transfer Team (CATS) can be contacted for advice on management and or transfer.
Paediatric general surgery:

All suspected Paediatric surgery cases who are under 5 years of age should be referred to the Paediatric ED consultant (if available) or Paediatric Registrar for review and onward referral if deemed necessary. All suspected Paediatric surgery cases who are over 5 years of age should be referred to the General surgeons for review and to formulate an initial management plan.
All Paediatric Orthopaedic cases should be referred to the orthopaedic surgeons.
All Paediatric Maxfax cases should be referred to the Maxfax surgeons.
All Paediatric Burns or plastics cases should be referred to the Burns or plastics team.
All Paediatric ENT cases should be referred to the ENT surgeons.
All Paediatric mental health patients without co-existing medical problems requiring intervention or treatment should be managed in line with the attached pathways (Refer to appendix 5 and 6)
Triage
Children and Young people should be assessed by a children's nurse (a nurse with at least 6months paediatric nursing experience and a current PILS or EPLS certification)

11.1.1 The triage nurse or nurse in charge in CED will assess all children. This assessment will include pain and CEWT scores, high-flow pathways and use of sepsis 6 pathways as appropriate. They will initiate treatment as required (i.e. antipyretic) and designate any child or young person directly to the appropriate team as per pathway and policy. The triage can happen either in triage room or paediatric major cubicle.
The triage and rapid initial assessment should be done within  minutes of registration in ED. If there is delay the escalation pathway should be followed. (Refer to appendix 1)
The child/young person will be seen in order of priority (as highlighted by the Triage system).

Every child/young person will have a CEWT (children's early warning tool) assessment at triage, which is documented in their record and appropriate action / escalation taken and clearly documented by medical and nursing staff.
The nurse making the assessment should take responsibility for the child until they formally hand over to another member of the team, admit or discharge the child home.
At shift handover all patients must be formally handed over to the nurse who will be taking responsibility until discharge or admission.
All children should have a pain score completed at triage. Analgesia is dispensed for moderate and severe pain within  minutes of arrival.
Assessment

Children's ED Internal Professional Standard: The triage and rapid initial assessment should be done within 15 minutes of registration in ED or arrival in PAU (Refer Table 1). If there is delay the escalation pathway should be followed.
Table 1: Key Performance indicators

escalation policy if target not being met

CEWT/clinical impression suggests need for immediate intervention
100% in Resus bay within 15 minutes Admission to appropriate clinical area within 3 hours (this may be remaining in resus)
Condition requiring admission beyond ED (e.g. PAU or Inpatient ward)
95% transferred to appropriate area (PAU or Inpatient ward) within 3 hours
Mental health concerns without associated medical condition
See attached mental health crisis pathway
Clinically critical: 60 minutes Discharge critical: 120 minutes from request
All pathology requests where immediate testing possible
Clinically critical: 60 minutes Discharge critical: 120 minutes from receipt in laboratory

data.text: Assessment in ED: The first assessment should be completed within 1 hour of triage by a doctor or paediatric ENP. If there is delay the escalation pathway should be followed (Refer to Table 2).
Table 2

table_items.text: Children have been initially triaged within 15 minutes, analgesia, antipyretics and/or fluid challenges have been administered or commenced
Children have a Management plan in place or have been discharged (refer to 09026 Children's Discharge Policy)

Treatment is in progress or they have been discharged If children with medical complaints have not been seen or are unlikely to be seen by ED medical staff within 4 hours, the ED consultant should be in the department assisting and allocate all available ED staff to help see patients.

All children have been admitted or discharged If there is still a backlog of medical children (i.e. non injuries or other specialty patients), the ED Consultant should be assisting in ED, have obtained all avaialable ED staff assistance and then should contact the Paediatric Consultant on-call to request assistance in seeing paediatric medical patients. The Paediatric Consultant can then manage staff within the Paediatric department to assist when possible.

data.text: If the child requires a referral to a Speciality team, they should be seen within 30 minutes of referral.

If any child is significantly unwell they should be seen by the ED consultant/Paediatric ED consultant (plus speciality registrar if appropriate) immediately. If there is any delay they must be escalated using the escalation pathway in line with the “CEWT escalation Aid” located on the back of all Paediatric observation charts and subsequently the “escalation of a deteriorating paediatric patient” (Refer to Appendix 3).
Escalation Principles for delays in care in ED.
Nursing staff follow (Appendix 1) if equity and capacity is high resulting in delays.

The following does not apply to children who warrant rapid clinical assessment due to abnormal CEWT scores or nursing concerns, refer to the “CEWT escalation Aid” for these patients and the “escalation of a deteriorating paediatric patient” (Appendix 3).

Assessment in PAU: The first assessment should be completed within 1 hour of arrival by a suitable doctor depending on the reason for attendance. If there is delay the escalation pathway should be followed (Refer to table 3).
Table 3

table_items.text: The first assessment of all patients should be completed
Children have a Management plan in place or have been discharged (see 09026 Children's Discharge Policy)
Treatment is in progress or they have been discharged If children have not been seen or are unlikely to be seen within 4 hours, the Paediatric consultant should be informed
All children have been admitted or discharged If there is still a backlog the Paediatric Consultant should be assisting and obtain all available Paediatric staff assistance.

data.text: The team accepting the child into PAU are responsible for managing the child until there is a formal acceptance by another team to take over the management of the patient.
If the child requires a referral to a Speciality team, they should be seen within 30 minutes of being accepted by the specialist team.

If any child is significantly unwell they should be seen by Paediatric Registrar and/or speciality registrar if appropriate immediately. If there is any delay they must be escalated. Clinical escalation in relation to children who are unwell should be in line with the CEWT escalation aid and the “escalation of a deteriorating paediatric patient” (Refer to appendix 3)

During the period of observation in the assessment unit, the observations should be recorded as required depending on the initial assessment. The planned frequency of observations should be recorded on the relevant age appropriate observation chart. The frequency of observations should be reviewed each time the child is reassessed and the CEWT score recorded.

When children are discharged home the family must be given information about where they should go if their child deteriorates, contact numbers for the ward and any other relevant parent information. A final clinical assessment of the child should be carried out by the nurse including recording vital signs and Children's Early Warning Tool (CEWT) score before the child leaves the ward.
All care, treatment and discussions with the child and family should be documented in line with the Clinical Record Keeping Policy (08086).
All treatments or decisions to admit must be completed within 4 hours.
Recognition of a Critically ill Child

Cardiac arrest in children is usually the result of respiratory and or circulatory failure that develops over time and is rarely a sudden event. The recognition of a critically ill child who may deteriorate is key to improving outcomes.

Clinical judgement and experience in recognising the critically ill or deteriorating child is of paramount importance. The use of a Children's Early Warning Tool (CEWT) has been introduced on the Children's Wards and the Emergency Department as an adjunct to the monitoring of unwell children to aid in the early recognition of serious illness. (Refer to CYP Observation Policy; register number 11046)

The staff should respond promptly to children whose score is 5-6 (red) or increasing as well as where there are other concerns (including parental concerns) about the child's clinical status. This scoring system has been introduced to support junior staff in the assessment of sick children and to be more objective in informing senior staff of the condition of the patient. The staff with clinical concerns about a child should not allow themselves to be falsely reassured by a low score.
Safeguarding

The safeguarding section of the assessment documentation must be completed for every child/young person and any safeguarding concerns must be clearly identified and appropriate onward referral made. If there is any doubt about the action to take, the children's safeguarding team/Paediatric ED consultants should be contacted in hours, out of hours advice can be sought form the paediatric registrar. (Refer to safeguarding children policy 04064)
Facilities
Toilet/bathroom facilities: there will be access to a toilet and changing facilities in Children's ED.
Sluice facilities: this is a shared facility with main ED department.
There is a vending machine in main reception area.
Medication Preparation: the medication will be stored in the Children's ED
Waiting areas: the children's ED have designated waiting area with play facilities for all age groups of children.
Emergency Department Staffing
Receptionist: 24/7 covers ED/CED
Nursing:
Band 7 senior sisters 2 WTE overall responsibility children's ED department.
Day time: 1 band 6 in-charge, 1 trained and 1 band 3 HCA.
Night time: 1 band 6 in-charge, 1 trained and 1 band 3 HCA.
Doctors:
Doctors covered by ED rota.
4 Paediatric ED Consultants covered by Paediatric Consultant rota.
Transfer
A child will be assessed and transferred to an appropriate environment which may include in-line with trust paediatric transfer policy: (Refer to appendix 4)
Theatre
Tertiary referral unit
Another District General Hospital (in the event of bed shortages)
Pharmacy

The department will be supported by Pharmacy. The patients go to pharmacy to collect prescribed medications during day (09:00-17:00). The department has supply of emergency medication to take away during out-of-hours.
Contingency Plans
If PAU is full patients will remain in ED to be managed.
Escalation policy for bed and staffing shortages.
Use of Equipment library if equipment shortage.
Emergency telephones, mobile phones if telephones go down.
Emergency corridor lighting available.
Oxygen cylinders available on the unit if disruption to gas supply.
Backup generator available.
All monitoring, pumps and infusion devices have battery back ups.
Clinical Governance

All incidents/DATIX reports are discussed each morning at the safety huddle for Women's and Children's Services. The incidents are then allocated to the appropriate person to investigate. Those incidents involving ED medical staffing will be sent to adult ED to investigate. Those incidents involving specialties such as surgery and plastics will be sent

to them to investigate. The Clinical Governance Facilitator for Women's and Children's works closely with the other Divisional Clinical Governance Facilitators and also with the Trust Governance Team to ensure that reporting, actions and recommendations are complete in line with Trust policy.

Concise and Comprehensive reports: where appropriate it may be deemed necessary for a concise or comprehensive report to be undertaken. This will be required in a timely fashion and the clinical governance facilitator will work closely with the investigating officer to ensure this is done. The decision as to the level of report required will be made either at the daily safety huddle by the Clinical Director and Lead Nurses or at the Trust Serious Incident Management Group (SIMG) meeting held daily by representatives of the Trust Governance Team.
Key Relationships
The Paediatric Service is provided by or works closely with the following services / staff:
Key Requirements
The department will meet the standards of the Children and Young People's National Service Framework (NSF) (2003)
Staffing will be suitable to meet the needs of the children and young people, the guidance from the Royal College of Nursing, Staffing Children's Wards document will be used.
Staff will have the appropriate training as identified in the mandatory training policy and NSF for children.

Staff will have appropriate training to ensure that they are able to meet the requirement to safeguard children during their assessment episode and that all Safeguarding Children policies and procedures are adhered to.

The service is fair, accessible and meets the needs of everybody; signposting and access are suitable to meet the needs of all our clients including wide doors for wheelchairs and double buggies and family friendly signage within the ward area.
All reception desks are low enough to allow children to see the faces of the staff sitting behind a desk.
Patient records to be available for planned admission, if notes are not available a temporary set are prepared.
A play specialist or nursery nurse will be available to support children and their families during their assessment episode and to assist with the preparation for painful or distressing procedures.
A chaperone is available to meet the requirements of the Chaperone Policy.
Specialist equipment is stored appropriately to ensure that the environment remains safe for the children and young people.
A separate room is available for nursing staff to treat and dress patients' wounds.
Psychotherapy Staff are given appropriate space and to enable them to meet children in the department in a quiet space where they are free from interruptions
Staff Training

All staff have mandatory and core skills training and departmental induction when they join the trust. Staff are allocated time to facilitate mandatory training. The doctors have a regular weekly teaching programme in ED and Paediatrics.
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Women's and Children's annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Paediatric Departmental Meeting and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Communication
Approved guidelines will be disseminated to appropriate staff via email after ratification of guideline.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 9)
References
NHS England (2003) National Service Framework Department of Health: April

With thanks to North East London Foundation Trust (NELFT) for supply of Pathway for Under  Years Requiring EWMHS Crisis Mental Health Assessment (appendix 5) and Escalation Procedure when a Young Person Requires a Psychiatric Inpatient Bed (Refer to Appendix 6)

Procedure for arranging medical cover out of hours (OOH)
Out of Hours (OOH) refer to the following times when the Medical Resource department is not operational
After 17.00 hours and before 07.30 hours Monday to Friday
Saturday and Sunday
All public holidays & bank holidays

Doctors  receiving  communication  are  requested  to  contact  the  appropriate Registrar/Consultant informing them of a potential shortfall as soon as possible. The Registrar/Consultant can be contacted via switchboard and in turn will inform the Site Operations Manager. Registrars should contact the appropriate Consultant on call also.

When a doctor contacts the appropriate Registrar/Consultant OOH and informs them that they are unable to fulfil their duties, the Site Operations Manager should be contacted and the following action should be implemented.
Review internal cover conjunction with the Consultant or Registrar on duty.

All the medical staffing rotas for the Trust are listed on the Trust Intranet under Clinical Pages and Doctors rosters – the rotas also contain the contact details for the doctors: http://meht-intranet/clinical-pages/doctors-rosters/
Once the internal cover has been exhausted, the Site Operations Manager will contact LMS who will outsource the shift to all agencies on the approved framework.
Locums must be booked within the TDA capped rates. Agency rates requested over and above the TDA/Monitor capped rates must have on call manager permission out of hours.
Agencies should not be requesting higher rates for doctors OOH. The Medical Resource Department must be notified if this happens.

If LMS cannot find a locum through framework suppliers –on call manager permission must be requested to use off frame work agencies. Off framework agencies are subject to the same compliance checks and the attached form must be completed and checked before approval for the doctor can be made. Compliance checks for TDA capped rates must also be adhered to.

If no alternative cover can be found, the Site Operations Manager will contact the appropriate Registrar/Consultant informing them of the need to realign internal services to ensure adequate safe cover (Acting down Policy may need to be followed).
The Site Operations Manager will be responsible for ensuring all the required recruitment checks are in place prior to the doctor commencing the duty.

If the agency locum booking was made during the OOH period specific employment details will be required (Medical Agency Doctors Compliance Checklist listed below must be filled in by the agency when submitting a doctor for the shift).
All OOH agency locum requests require specific requirements to be met i.e. competencies, these must be agreed with by the Consultant on call depending on the specialty requiring the cover.

The Site Operations Managers must ensure the attached checklist is completed and returned to the Medical Resource department daily to ensure accurate records of instances such as sick leave and locum bookings are maintained.
If approval has been given to breach CAP rates or use an off framework agency the Medical Resource department must be informed.
If locum cover cannot be sourced internally or externally the CD/Consultant is responsible for realigning all available resources to ensure that the department has adequate cover.
Induction Packs

Induction packs are delivered to the Security Office included in the packs will be a photograph of the doctor, details on how to access the Trusts IT systems and IT access and if attending for the first time an induction checklist.

If the doctor is attending for the first time an induction checklist will need to be completed by the doctor following the photographic check. This check list must be returned with the ID badge to the Security Office on completion of the shift.
If the doctor has attended in the past only the photographic evidence will be required and the Security officer will give their ID badge and IT access.
Any doctors attending the ED department on a regular basis will have permanent IT access and ID badge.
Locums can access induction information and the guides to the Trust IT systems Via the Trust intranet:
http://meht-intranet/clinical-pages/doctors-locum-doctors-information-pack/
